Award.AwardTitle: UNS Proposal for conference support for the 2015 InterPACK/ICNMM conference July 6-9 in San Francisco, CA

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal request conference support for student participation in the 2015 InterPACK/ICNMM conference, July 6-9, in San Francisco, CA.

The NSF funding will be used to offer 17 travel grants to both female graduate students and students from under-represented minority groups. The opportunities of this NSF grant will benefit these student participants in broadening their educational experience and preparing them for their careers with a preview of professional and technical communities.

Institution.Name: Villanova University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VILLANOVA UNIVERSITY IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant was for conference support for the 2015 InterPACK conference, held July 6-9 2015 at the Fairmont San Francisco Hotel, in downtown San Francisco. The conference was co-located with the International Conference on Nanochannels, Microchannels and Minichannels (ICNMM). The goals of this support were to subsidize the participation expenses of underrepresented minority and female graduate students and to enhance their experience by providing workshop and networking opportunities specifically developed for them.

The outcomes of the grant were as follows:

The funding was used to provide travel grants for 13 graduate students to the conference.  These 13 students included 10 women, 1 native Hawaiian male and one Hispanic male. The travel grants were used to cover the conference fee, hotel and limited travel to/from San Francisco.  The amount varied but averaged almost $900 per student.

Funding was also used to support the development of two new events at the conference: a Graduate Student Career workshop and a Panel on Women in Technical Careers. The Graduate Student Workshop on Career Paths drew approximately 50-75 graduate students and provided a dedicated opportunity for graduate students to interact with both industry and academic scientists and engineers. The workshop kicked off a brief panel presentation with industry and academic engineers talking about their career paths.  After the panel, workshop transitioned to small group discussions involving distinguished researchers in both academic and industry careers.  Fourteen mentors were available to talk directly with the students, 7 from industry and 7 from academics.  Students were engaged in small group discussion with one mentor for 30 minutes (see attached images) and then they rotated to a second mentor for an additional 30 minutes. The relaxed and informal atmosphere, facilitated open conversation between students and mentors.

The panel on Women in Technical Careers drew about 15-20 female graduate students and professionals in attendance, along with a few interested male attendees.  The panel featured three high achieving female researchers, speaking about their career paths.  The panel had both industry and academic representation.  The discussion period was lively with the audience actively asking numerous questions of our panelists. Many of the young women expressed that having the opportunity to interact with female mentors was invaluable to them.
